we are the maker of Sopris assistant
which is which is a digital assistant
for clinicians that automates their

other applications to really improve how
documentation is done in healthcare and

around using voice and AI for clinical

health is as I mentioned as a company
were based in Denver Colorado and it's a
company whose whose mission is to make
clinical documentation easy for
everybody and really reduce and remove
the the burden and most the time it
takes to do documentation and really our
broader vision is something that we call
intelligent clinical operations and
really what we're working toward is a
platform based in voice in AI that
enables healthcare providers to rethink
how they deliver care not being tied to
a PC computer and a desktop and a mouse
and all those kinds of things so that's
really what we're working toward and as
we've been you know going through this
journey the the first lesson that I want
to share with you is in the area of WHO
and by this we mean whom are we serving
right who are we trying to help and I
think you all are probably familiar with
this problem statement that that
clinicians are spending 50% of their day
doing documentation
be percent of their day doing
commutation that's a number that's come
out of multiple studies and and they're
spinning barely over half at with
patience alright so I think most people
would agree that that feels pretty
backward and the cost of the industry is
massive three-quarters of a billion
dollars but what many people may not
know is that this is not just about
physicians it's usually phrased in terms
of physicians and physician burnout and
physician documentation but it's not
just physicians you have pas you have
nurse practitioners you have nurses who
are seeing patients who are documenting
those encounters and there are four
times as many of them as there are
physicians so we care very much about
helping the doctors but we find that the
conversation is usually focused
exclusively on the physicians the
solutions that are out there in the
market are almost entirely for
physicians and there's this entire
underserved market or really unserved

for fists or 80 percent of clinicians
are not being served by the existing
solutions so that that was the first
lesson that we drew was to it was to
really broaden our our own view of this
and to say that yes
doctors need help but to really remember
that we need to build a solution that
works for everyone and one of the most
important things about that is it really
means a different price point
generally speaking provider
organizations are able to spend more
money to solve a problem for a doctor
than they are for for a nurse or even a
PA or a nurse practitioner so it really
means that you have to have a fully
automated technology which which will
have the cost foundation to get to a
price point that works for these other
groups so that's really one of the key
things that that we've learned and that
we really factor into how we deliver our
solution second thing I want to share
with you is as what so what
when when we're building technologies
those of you who build technology for a

what are the jobs to be done the
problems to be solved and we've spent a
lot of time analyzing this and we spent

but it was important we wanted to spend
the time really digging into figuring
out how these workflows work where are
the pain points where are the
opportunities what are the problems to
be solved
and the jobs to be done and one of the
key things that we really extracted from
this is because there are a lot of ways
to think about this but I think one of
the easy ways to think about it is in
terms of what clinicians call pajama
time who's familiar with this term
couple people okay so pajama time is the
term that means this is when we're doing
charting and medical documentation at
home at night right so it's so common
that it's it's gotten this nickname and
it's very frequently you know an hour
and a half two hours being spent in the
evenings on the weekends obviously time
away from family but it also takes away
time from you know from work from being
able to see other patients so this is
obviously something that we find is sort
of a useful way to think about it
because one it has a strong emotional
component when you say pajama time to a
doctor or another clinician alright they
know what that means and they
experienced that but it also has a
practical implication to to the
organization's right this is time spent
either not seeing patients which affects
access and and financial metrics for the
organization but it also affects burnout
right because it's time not spent with
family so pajama time is a big thing and
what we found is that where this comes
from is it on average a clinician will
spend between five and fifteen minutes
documenting an encounter so every time
you go to see a doctor you go see a PA
they're going to spend however much time
they spend with you
usually 15 minutes or so like that then
they'll spend almost as much time
sometimes more actually documenting the
time that they spent with you so but
they don't have time in between patients
usually and so that gets saved up to the
end of the day and that's where the hour
and a half two hours comes from so
that's sort of the that's sort of the
picture here and so so our goal is to
eliminate pajama time we're not going to
eliminate documentation entirely but how
do we squeeze it into a space where it
doesn't take up nights and weekends well
so what we figured out is that
clinicians have in between patients
usually no scheduled time so what time
do they have well they have the time
that it takes essentially to walk from
one exam room to the next so I finished
talking to this patient I walk down the
hall to go talk to my other patient and
that's usually about 45 to 60 seconds
that's kind of how much time now so what
we realized was we had to take five or
ten minutes of documentation work and
squeeze it in at 45 seconds so that
became that became our job that was the
that was the the mission that we took on
and so second lesson to get rid of
pajama time you got to squeeze 5-10
minutes of documentation work into 45
seconds that's pretty universal across
specialties whether you're talking
inpatient outpatient this this we found
is a pretty use Universal formula so now
the challenge became well how do you do

already been done so we really spent a
lot of time and I'll tell you we didn't

probably the second time we really spent
we took a couple of cuts at this because
it's a hard problem and so I'll tell you
kind of here's one of the things that we
that we tried first and then I'll kind
of tell you where we ended up so one of
the first things that we did is we said
well a lot of doctors have scribes who's
seen a scribe anybody seen a scribe when
you go in to see the doctor okay so
you're familiar with this so scribe is
if you haven't if you're not familiar
with this when you go and see the doctor
there might be a third person sitting in
the room with a laptop and that person
is listening to the conversation and
documenting the conversation as you talk

assistant that follows the doctor around
all day and some doctors have them and
they can be really helpful in solving

kind of an expensive solution to the
problem and then you know they have to
get trained and then they leave and all

model for us because we said gee if we
could build a technology that sort of
does part of what a scribe does could
you build a technology that listens to
the conversation between the doctor and
the patient and knows enough that it can
extract key information right so this is
also kind of a cool technology challenge
right Wow
could you build a technology that would
stream the audio and it would understand
enough about this type of conversation
that we could extract information out
and it would know when the doctors
talking about the medication it would
know when the doctors talking about the
history or the treatment plan or when
they want you to come in for a follow-up

are your kids doing right it would be
able to parse all that out and
understand it so we did this we built
this technology and it worked well we
used it in live in clinics we actually
had paying customers using this every
day with their patients and 5,000 is
actually a little low it's more than
that we it's been used live and a lot of
visits actually we still have some users
who are using this technology who are
gonna in the process of moving over to

so we did this based on an iPhone it
worked well as you can see we were
testing it at about 91% accuracy for for

that's a good number right if you ask

really good number if you ask your

thing so so we learned two things two
really important lessons that we took
from this one lesson is those
conversations don't contain all the data
that you need to do all the
documentation so if you think about when
you go in and you see your doctor or
again any other clinician your nurse PA
nurse practitioner you have a
conversation with them that conversation
useful data in it for the purposes of
documentation but it doesn't have all
the data you need to do all the
documentation so we were able to
automatically generate parts of the note
and we found that it was really useful
but it wasn't totally complete so what
we realized is this is a great feature
it's not a full product right so
definitely useful we're actually going
to be integrating this technology into a

do think it's a really useful thing and
there are some other folks that are

think it's worthwhile but again it's not
it's not a it can't do the full job just
based on the conversation second thing
we learned is that 91% accuracy is a

technology it's not a great number for
documentation solution unassisted and so
what we did was we had some people in

have some people on the back end who

the clinician and they were very happy
so it worked well as a product but of
course adding a person into the loop
adds time and cost right so that's ok
right it's fine you can actually build a

checking back to our first lesson right
what was our first lesson our first

implies a certain price point that when

basically kind of
you know we spent we we interviewed over

this like one of them responds to me
Alexa tell me the weather right and so
it can respond to a command like that
but there are a couple of problems with

clinical documentation that's not nearly
fast enough
the second is those are really simple
interactions and we need to be able to

documentation is is there's a lot of
content a lot of nuance to it and it
also puts the onus on the user to
remember what are the commands I can say
right you probably remember the first
time you started using one of these
things you had to train yourself right
how do I talk to it what can I say and
we we wanted we didn't want to put that
burden on the user so what we did is we
we flipped the model of a digital
assistant so we call this so Chris
assistant and the way it works is it's
trained so we've trained it to
understand how to do documentation for
all the typical visit types for a given
specialty so if you're in an urgent care
setting let's say you see people coming
in for flu shots you see people coming
in for bumps and scrapes you see people
coming in for a sinus infection of a
variety of things we trained the
assistant to understand what those visit
types are how to document each one and
then it knows what questions to ask the
clinician to finish its work right so
that's what I mean by flip the model so
the assistant leads the conversation and
so it really reduces we
found the cognitive load on the user so
the user doesn't have to remember what
can I say
the user just has to answer questions
that the assistant is asking and then we
use this it's not an image of it up here

the next slide so we we use this chat
interface to make it kind of a natural

with another challenge that we solve for
there are a lot of layers to this onion
is that people want this problem solved
but they don't want to change their
behavior in order to solve the problem
so what we found was we had to bring
something that was really new and solve

that didn't require behavior change and
it would feel familiar would feel like
an old pair of shoes and so this was the
approach that we landed on like any
problem there there's more than one

we use this chat interface so we use a

it needs to be optimized for speed so
the user can speak responses but they
can also tap on answers that are
suggested by the assistant which
frequently we found is faster than

for each one of these questions can
decide how they want to respond so
